displayed_text: Patient: I I think sh-she wants to um call for me. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yup. Mhm. Doctor: Alright, so I will be in touch with you as soon as I have that, the result. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Nice to see you again. Patient: Same here. Doctor: Thank you. Patient: socks. Doctor: I know. Doctor: I’ll be wearing it next time.

Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: That lasts for a whole year so that you don’t have to get injections. Some people like that because it’s convenient. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have to go back and forth. But typical most common ways is to get an injection every twelve weeks which is like every three months. Patient: Right. Family Member: And when he does that does he see you at that time? Doctor: Yeah me and if people live around her they see me. If you know have a relationship with Dr. F__ and that’s closer. Family Member: I would like to keep you both though because I think you know it would be more convenient to be close to home and I know they have state-of-the-art equipment there because I’ve already talked to the manager of the cancer center and um and then to still be coming here. To me it is. If that’s okay with you. Doctor: Do you want me to send him a text right now? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah? (pause) Family Member: That’s fine.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it will create more scarring and that’s a different thing than the prostate. Patient: I had none from that da Vinci procedure. Doctor: We will, we will get in, we will get out with these samples, done. Now you know anytime we poke there’s always a downside because you’re poking… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …bleeding, infection, you could pop something, uh admission, any of the above. So… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …I don’t think it’ll happen. The radiology guys will go over that. Um from a research standpoint, we hang onto your stuff. If any point in time you’re like (pfft) Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …Otherwise we literally try to maximize as much information as possible from your stupid cancer. Patient: Well as I as I said, if… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …if, if it’s anywhere, if it’s, if it’s the same people that did the port if it’s people that as are as competent as the people that did the port, I have no problem with it at all.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We always got to watch your blood counts, because we always got to watch your blood counts. And that means white cells, red cells, platelets, and then of course, liver and kidney numbers. But that's blood tests. So you don't necessarily feel bad from that. We do know that some patients, their platelets go down a little bit. And that in some other patients, you might get a little bit of stomach upset. So not like full blown oh my gosh, you can't eat anything. And if that is the case, then we would have to, you know, modify the medication dose. But you can get a slight, you know, nausea or upset stomach. So we'd have to figure out how that plays with you. Other than that, that’s about it, so it's basically another hormone pill. So Xtandi, tackles one pathway of the receptor. This pill is another pathway. They are somewhat related, but this is not a chemo, it's actually another hormone. Yeah. So we're just trying to make sure you're super castrated, and then some, and then some. Patient: There’s that euphemism for the Prius. Patient: So, how does it affect my heart? Doctor: So obviously, we have to make sure that we take care of it, it shouldn't affect there's no direct effect, you know, it's not like, here's the chemo and Oh, boy. The Xtandi is, you know, always has a potential for heart issues, because we can't say that it doesn't, because anything that touches that testosterone pathway puts you in more of a menopause and accelerates heart disease. But that's true with your, you know, Lupron, that's true for all the other pills you've been on. Unfortunately, that's the main sort of active drug with all of this with prostate cancer. So that's the tough part. This one shouldn't have a cardiac thing. But again, this is a study. So if you do have a worsening cardiac thing that's reportable, because we would want to make sure that no other person has that. Patient: So they don't know that? Doctor: Oh, no, this is why it's a study. I mean, this is- you’re guinea pig, once again, you know, like you tell us what's going on. But it isn't like this is a chemo or something that we're really worried that this might worsen heart disease. But it's always this- every time you fool around with the hormone receptors, you know, it can worsen heart disease in general. So I don't know about this particular combo, but that's why it's on a study and not me just go in here, take this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What else? Patient: And for how long does this study last? Doctor: As long as you respond, we keep going. So if you are side effects, or too much, or you're like, Listen, I'm just done, we stop. If you say my gosh, this thing is really good. And I'm doing great, we keep going. And it's we can't take the drug away from you. Sometimes that's to the irritation of the pharma company, because sometimes they want to get out after a year, but it's actually interesting. One of my other studies, somebody's been on two years longer than they thought, and they want to close it. And we're like, well, I'm sorry, my one guy's doing great. So you can't take it away from us. So there's that other option, but in general, it's you who calls it quits or that the cancer’s has moved on. And if that's happened, we got to stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Mhm.

Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I don’t see any reason to cancel that. Family Member: Unless you want to – so it doesn’t matter whether we sign the consent today or that day to you. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So when’s the next time I come in to I guess there? There’s no way of doing it here? Doctor: It’s too much. Family Member: I think it’s a echocardiogram… Healthcare Professional: Phase I. Patient: Can I bring a book? Doctor: Oh yeah, yeah. They even have movies and they have a TV there. Family Member: You’re gonna bring me too. I’m definitely coming to this. Doctor: They have all kinds of stuff to do there.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: The computer makes the decision as to whether you get the extra drug or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And there always is the possibility that when you go through some of this checking, you’re not eligible. Patient: Um. Doctor: Okay, I think we have ninety days from when you got your first shot, which was November six or seven – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to get things going. And so that’s why I put this appointment on the books. So let’s get the hormones started. You know you will say, “I want it; I don’t want it; I do want it.” In other words I’m not trying to put, you know but we have to have and then your opinion back. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So we weren’t making any decisions. So I’m delighted today that you feel better, that you can’t complain of anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: Your creatinine is down at one. And then if you’re still interested, then we would go for it. If you say, “I’m not interested”, if you’re not interested then you have to think about when do we start you know the chemotherapy. And that’s what we would probably do anyway. If you go through the process about the trial and they say you’re not eligible, then we would give the chemo anyway. Patient: Yeah anyway.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, M___’s lookin’ to see. We have about two trials to consider. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But one of them, I just gotta make sure. The one that I am thinking of, I have to make sure that there is an opening. You know how the drill goes. Family Member: Yes. Yes. Doctor: But the good news is the scans were just done. It really does not show. Patient: That’s good. Doctor: That it’s gone “kablooee.” Yeah. Patient: The only thing that was concerning me Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Was that occasionally I have some hip pain, but I don’t. Ya know.. Doctor: Mm-hmm. Patient: You know, I’m not sure that that’s not.. uh, oh

Healthcare Professional: So fatigue is a big one. Patient: I have plenty of fatigue. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Family Member: You’ll be tired. Doctor: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Um um well let me see. (Laughing) Doctor: Sometimes we see your blood numbers for your liver and how they function, sometimes that gets a little bit screwed up. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that but some things we have to monitor. We always say anything with pills can affect your, your, you know your stomach and your bowels. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Doc -so that’s possible. You could get diarrhea or constipation – Healthcare Professional: Um hum.

Patient: Keep goin’ with my pain medicine – Doctor: Take that as you need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: And then – so we got that out of the way. Doctor: Got that out of the way. Patient: Then you’re gonna schedule me up to get the yoo-yoo. Doctor: The yoo-yoo’s the biopsy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: He knows he has to have it. He knows he just had a scan. M_’s gonna go as quick as she can to get things rollin’. So. Healthcare Professional 2: Well, can you come Tuesday? (Laughs) Patient: Next Tuesday?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - then there’s no question that hormone therapy will cause more side effects than radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: There’s no question about that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, if your goal is to try to eradicate as much of the cancer as fast as possible – Family Member: Um hum. DOC - then the best way to do that although it’s still not a cure is hormone therapy plus or minus something else. So something new. Doctor: Right, so there’s no question that hormone therapy within the first three months is going to kill like ninety-nine percent of the cancer. Happens with almost everyone. With radiotherapy you know there’s a decent chance that it’s going to kill whatever cancer happens to be part that we radiate – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - but the rest of the cancer which is going to be invisible is obviously going to be outside of that radiation field. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: It’s not going to be touched. And the concern with that is although I am a proponent of someone that wants to – If your goal is absolutely to avoid hormone therapy as long as possible, that’s a good option for you. And again, what would be driving that would be more quality of life.

Family Member: Now, at the end of the trial catheter, how do they go uh with that? Do they have to wait for the catheter to come out in order start clinical trials or or, Doctor: That’s after you’ve sat down with D and signed the paperwork. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then they’ll do the extra tests to see that you’re eligible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there are steps and then if you’re working with a urologist and he or she is able to get it out, that’s great. If they feel like it needs to stay in and that isn’t something that excludes you from the study or that just will tell me that if I’m giving you chemotherapy your blood counts can get low. If your blood counts are low and you’ve got a tube in your bladder, you could have an infection. So that I might give you antibiotics to keep you from getting an infection because you’ve got the tube in. Patient: Um. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it just lets me be aware that I’ve got to be extra careful I’m giving you the chemotherapy. But it could be the one thing that sort of says oh he’s not eligible because he’s got a tube in his body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or maybe they don’t care one bit. Patient: Um.

Patient: I ain’t seen it in my lymph nodes. I check my lymph nodes. I ain’t seen none in my lymph nodes. Doctor: Well, you can’t see it. It’s inside when I do scans. So the good part is you don’t hurt or feel bad. Thank goodness. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that’s great. But it doesn’t mean that we don’t do stuff because that’s why I check scans because it’s inside. So that’s, that’s why. Family Member: Um. Okay. Doctor: So that’s where we’re at. Family Member: That’s the proper response. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And, uh, I’m still ready to ask. Doctor: Yep? Family Member: Oh. I ran into a lady.

Family Member: Oh, oh, he can? Doctor: Yeah. It’s only those four days. Family Member: OOH! It’s the first of the week of the week that you get it. Doctor: Of the week you get it, I don’t want you on the plane Thursday through Sunday. Patient: Right. Doctor: But the rest of the time you’re free. So you can go on the twenty-sixth. If you go on the eighth you can go; if you have chemo on the eighth you can go. Patient: Well when would my next day? Is it monthly or is it weekly? Doctor: It’s every three weeks. Patient: It’s every three weeks. Doctor: You’ll be fine. Patient: Okay, perfect. Doctor: And we can Patient: So when I get it on the eighth in terms of my work schedule; I’m an attorney; if I have a trial like the ninth or the tenth, can I -

Patient: Right. Doctor: And you were in the hospital for seven days. Patient: Seven days. Yes and the numbers went from eight point six down to one point seven when it went out. Family Member: No, down to two point four. Patient: I’m sorry, yeah, to two point four, and then after that it was even more. So the last reading I had was Doctor: They didn’t put any tubes in your kidneys? They didn’t put inside your body? Patient: That’s it. Doctor: Just the catheters. Family Member: Because he was improving; results were uh coming in. You know kidneys back into you know. Patient: They were getting better everyday, yeah. Doctor: They adjusted your blood pressure medicine. Patient: Correct. That is one thing that they did. They said the first time it was not good for the kidneys.

Family Member: He said he hides them. Doctor: I guess I don’t even. I didn’t even know that. Patient: Oh yeah, because I took one when I was down there and the guy (she gets after me for swiping people’s pens) Doctor: So mine are, you’re allowed to swipe. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, you can throw these away. (chuckles) Doctor: Well I use them so much; I mean I run out of ink and then I need to be able to toss and then move on to the next one. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. HCP Okay, so these will be sent. Do we have a - Doctor: In the R___, Yeah. (Pause 10 second) Patient: Oh yeah, they’re like, the pens he has are just like Cadillacs; they’re big. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: They’re big but they’re light-weight, and they have the new type points on them. Doctor: My gosh, you do notice stuff. Wow! Even I didn’t know that.
